key_points: The accidental shooting deaths on movie sets are rare, with Brandon Lee's 1993 death being notably referenced in relation to the 2021 'Rust' incident.
Both the 1993 and 2021 shootings involved real, functional guns that were supposed to be safe but weren't properly checked.
Brandon Lee died on the set of 'The Crow' due to a fragment of a lead bullet lodged in a gun barrel; Halyna Hutchins was killed on the 'Rust' set.
Jerry Spivey, the former district attorney for Wilmington, chose not to file criminal charges after Lee's death, citing a lack of evidence for criminal intent.
The 'Rust' shooting is under investigation; no criminal charges have been filed yet, but all options are being considered.
New Mexico Governor has called for state legislation regarding safety protocols on film sets.
Brandon Lee's death led to a lawsuit by his family, settled for an undisclosed amount.
The 'Crow' producers and Lee's family agreed releasing the film was best to honor his performance.
Calls for reform in the use of real guns on movie sets have intensified after both incidents.
The incidences highlight concerns over safety measures and protocol compliance on movie sets.
spokespersons: James Janowitz (New York Lawyer, represented 'The Crow' producers)
New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham
